16. Liu, J., Song, M., Horton, R. & Hu, Y. Reducing spread in climate model projections of a September ice-free Arctic.
. The next generation of scenarios for climate change research and assessment.

Colorado USA (2016, updated daily, accessed 6 April 2017).
19. Walsh, J. E., Chapman, W. L. & Fetterer, F. Gridded monthly sea ice extent and concentration, 1850 onwards. Tech. Rep. Version 1.1,
National Snow and Ice Data Center, Boulder, CO, USA (2015).

. Global analyses of sea surface temperature, sea ice, and night marine air temperature since the late nineteenth
. History of sea ice in the Arctic.
. Modeled trends in Antarctic sea ice thickness.
. A model reconstruction of the Antarctic sea ice thickness and volume changes over 1980–2008 using data
25. Steele, M., Ermold, W. & Zhang, J. Arctic Ocean surface warming trends over the past 100 years.
26. Carton, J. A., Ding, Y. & Arrigo, K. R. The seasonal cycle of the Arctic Ocean under climate change.
27. Stroeve, J. C., Markus, T., Boisvert, L., Miller, J. & Barrett, A. Changes in Arctic melt season and implications for sea ice loss.
28. Schweiger, A., Lindsay, R., Vavrus, S. & Francis, J. Relationships between Arctic sea ice and clouds during autumn.
29. Screen, J., Simmonds, I., Deser, C. & Tomas, R. The atmospheric response to three decades of observed Arctic sea ice loss.
30. Rainville, L. & Woodgate, R. A. Observations of internal wave generation in the seasonally ice-free Arctic.
31. Martin, T., Steele, M. & Zhang, J. Seasonality and long-term trend of Arctic Ocean surface stress in a model.
. Recent Arctic Ocean sea ice loss triggers novel fall phytoplankton blooms.
. Ecological consequences of sea ice decline.
34. Serreze, M. C. & Barry, R. G. Processes and impacts of arctic amplification: A research synthesis.
35. Screen, J. A. & Simmonds, I. The central role of diminishing sea ice in recent Arctic temperature amplification.
. Contribution of sea ice loss to Arctic amplification.
37. Screen, J. A., Deser, C. & Simmonds, I. Local and remote controls on observed Arctic warming.
38. Perlwitz, J., Hoerling, M. & Dole, R. Arctic tropospheric warming: Causes and linkages to lower latitudes.
39. Screen, J. A. & Francis, J. A. Contribution of sea-ice loss to Arctic amplification is regulated by Pacific Ocean decadal variability.
40. Curry, J. A., Schramm, J. E. & Ebert, E. E. On the ice albedo climate feedback mechanism.
41. Serreze, M. C. & Francis, J. A. The Arctic amplification debate.
42. Serreze, M. C., Barrett, A. P., Stroeve, J. C., Kindig, D. N. & Holland, M. M. The emergence of surface-based Arctic amplification.
44. Holland, M. M. & Bitz, C. M. Polar amplification of climate change in coupled models.
45. Graversen, R. G., Langen, R. L. & Mauritsen, T. Polar amplification in CCSM4: Contributions from the lapse rate and surface albedo

47. Steel e, M. & Di cki nson, S. The phenol ogy of Arct i c Ocean surf ace warmi ng.
48. Maslanik, J., Stroeve, J., Fowler, C. & Emery, W. Distribution and trends in arctic sea ice age through spring 2011.
49. Stroeve, J. & Notz, D. Insights on past and future sea-ice evolution from combining observations and models.
50. Walsh, J. E. A data set on northern hemisphere sea ice extent, 1953–76. Tech. Rep. Glaciol. Data Rep. GD-2, Arctic Sea Ice, Part 1,
World Data Cent. for Glaciol., Boulder, Colo (1978).
51. Comiso, J. C. Bootstrap Sea Ice Concentrations from Nimbus-7 SMMR and DMSP SSM/I-SSMIS, Version 2.1. Tech. Rep., NASA
National Snow and Ice Data Center Distributed Active Archive Center, Date accessed: 23 Jun 16 (2000).
52. Notz, D. How well must climate models agree with observations?
The authors thank three anonymous reviewers and the editor for their valuable comments which improved the
paper. The U.S. National Science Foundation supported this work (award FESD 1338814 and OCE 1129895).
TM acknowledges support from GEOMAR. The sea ice index data and Bootstrap data are from the U.S. NSIDC.
For their roles in producing, coordinating, and making available the CMIP5 model output, we acknowledge the
climate modeling groups, the World Climate Research Programme’s Working Group on Coupled Modelling, and
the Global Organization for Earth System Science Portals. Paul Holland and François Massonnet provided the
